Our aim is to ensure universal and lasting access to water and sanitation and hygiene as fundamental human rights. Unrestricted funding is essential to the way we work; It provides us with the flexibility to carry out work that is not covered by grants restricted to specific projects. This enables us to be more innovative,  and work on activities that are crucial  in  maximising our impact but may produce results that are hard to measure.  For example, it can help us to empower communities, support inclusion, and influence decision makers such as local and national government. It can be used to build the capacity of our staff and partner organisations, to monitor, research and learn from our work and share learning with others.  Finally, it provides our programmes with financial sustainability to ensure critical work can continue where there are funding gaps and unexpected costs.

The GTF programme is a £5 million  DFID funded programme over 5  years across 16 countries in Africa, Asia and Central America aiming to improve Accountability and Responsiveness of the duty bearers for an effective WASH delivery

This grant is part of a global program on WASH in schools that will deliver results and impact at various levels, both direct improvements in access to WASH for students, and by contributing to more long-term changes in national and global policies. Service delivery and national advocacy work will be implemented in Tanzania, Ethiopia, Uganda, Pakistan and India, and involve the two regional teams of East Africa and South Asia. Regional teams will deliver on research and advocacy and support CPs.
Six WASH projects under the HSBC Water Programme (rural)

Support requested for a 3-year plan to provide sustainable water access to marginalized rural communities in Ghana, Mali and Niger (October 2014-September 2017). The proposed project will build on lessons learned from CNHF-supported programs (April 2011-March 2014), by fine tuning successful approaches and critically assessing failed ones, while focusing on the factors affecting water systems’ functionality and the enabling environment for external support.

This Project will be implemented in three districts in Malawi namely; Nkhotakota, Kasungu and Machinga. The project will among others ensure that pregnant women and mothers have access to sustainable and inclusive WASH both at community and health facility levels; that good hygiene behaviour change
The main goal of the project is hence to contribute to poverty reduction in Konso through provision of safe water, improved sanitation facilities and promotion of hygiene practices.

The primary objective of WaterAid's AACES project is to improve access to water, sanitation and hygiene in underserved communities and schools in rural and urban areas of Tanzania, Malawi and Ghana. This will be undertaken through a combination of service delivery, capacity building and policy and influencing activities.

This grant will be used to support policy-focused sanitation and health campaigns and policy shifts at the global level as well as in West Africa and South Asia, to contribute to universal access to sanitation for the poorest worldwide, but especially in West Africa and South Asia.

This three year, multi country (Ethiopia, Malawi, Uganda) consortium [WaterAid, British Geological Survey, Overseas Development Institute, Kings College London, Addis Ababa University, Malawi University, Makarere University] study aims to get statistically significant data about the primary causes of water source failure. This will inform better targeting of resources to address sustainability challenges in the future.

66,429 schoolchildren, 2,253 teachers and 19,253 community members benefit from raised awareness of WASH rights and menstrual hygiene management for women and girls.

87,935 people in Nepal and Pakistan gain access to sustainable, inclusive WASH services including schoolgirls and teachers in 214 schools and women and girls in the community who are enabled to manage menstruation hygienically and with dignity.
Awareness raising and capacity development of local, district and provincial level institutions to contribute to the development and implementation of national policies on inclusive school WASH
Contribute to achieving gender equality in schools and surrounding communities through increased access to inclusive water, sanitation and hygiene in targeted regions of Nepal and Pakistan.
Contribute to the achievement of SDG 6 and SDG 3 in Sierra Leone and Mozambique
Contribute towards sustainable water and sanitation and improved health for marginalised communities in Ethiopia, Malawi and Rwanda.
CSOs and local communities empowered and demanding / responding to their rights to WASH services
Healthy hygiene behaviors promoted in target communities, schools and healthcare centres

Improved and equitable access to sustainable water, sanitation and hygiene for 121,694 marginalised people including mothers and new-borns, to contribute to improved health in targeted communities of Ethiopia, Malawi and Rwanda.
Increased access to equitable and sustainable WASH services for 94,190 people in targeted and marginalised rural districts of Sierra Leone and Mozambique
